title: Manage persistent storage for the suite
content:
This topic describes the storage sizing requirements for the suite, and also gives performance recommendations for the storage.

Storage sizing requirements

The suite uses many persistent volumes. In a production environment, the volume sizes increase over time. For a new installation, you must meet the initial volume sizing requirements; after the system goes live, you need to monitor the storage usage on a regular basis and take actions as needed. 

The tables in this section provides a list of the persistent volumes that the suite uses (not including those used for OMT), their initial sizing requirements for each deployment size (Small, Medium, or Large), how often you need to monitor their storage usage, and what actions you may need to take. 

The storage requirements are split into two performance groups: standard and high performance, based on the performance requirements.

Service Management supports using StorageClass (for dynamic volume provisioning). It supports two storage classes: itom-standard, and itom-fast, for standard performance storage and high performance storage, respectively. You need to map itom-standard, and itom-fast with your own storage class names.

A deployment on Azure uses both Azure Files and Azure Disks. The standard performance storage (itom-standard) volumes below use Azure Files (with shared storage space), and the high performance (itom-fast) volumes use Azure Disks (with separate storage space for each volume). 

Standard performance storage

This section lists the persistent volumes that the suite uses and their initial sizing requirements for a Helm deployment.

StorageClass
 Non-production (GB) Small (GB) Medium (GB) Large (GB) Usage Action Threshold  Monitoring
Interval		 Comments
data-volume
 itom-standard 50 200 200 200

data file 

  • vault (which store vault data)
  • share1 and share2 folders (which store ticket attachments)
  • other (all other service deployment data)
  • For the share1 and share 2 folders: 
    • Extend the disk space
 80% 1 week
config-volume itom-standard 20 100 100 100

configuration file

  • certificate
  • idol
    ... 
 Extend the disk space 80% 1 month
logging-volume itom-standard 100 500 500 500 log file
  • Each platform pod creates 2 GB logs
  • Each platform-offline pod creates 3 GB logs
  • Other service pod created logs
  • For logs:
    • Clean up logs
    • Extend the disk space
  • Other: 
    • Extend the disk space
 80% 1 month Each platform pod creates 2 GB logs
Each platform-offline pod creates 3 GB logs
 Total size (GB) 170 800 800 800

High performance storage

This section lists the persistent volumes that the suite uses and their initial sizing requirements for high performance storage.

 
StorageClass
 Non-production (GB) Small (GB) Medium (GB) Large (GB) Usage Action Threshold  Monitoring
Interval		 Comments
rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-0 itom-fast 1 2 6 12 Service Management message queue Extend the disk space 80% 1 month  
rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-1 itom-fast 1 2 6 12 Service Management message queue Extend the disk space 80% 1 month  
rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-2 itom-fast 1 2 6 12 Service Management message queue Extend the disk space 80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-0 itom-fast 5 15 30 60 Search data 

If the number of Content Groups is less than 6: 

  • Extend the disk space
  • Scale out (requires extra CPU and memory)

If the number of Content Groups is 6: 

  • Extend the disk space
 80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-1 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-2 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-3 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-4 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-5 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-0 itom-fast 5 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-1 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-2 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-3 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-4 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-5 itom-fast 1 15 30 60 Search data  80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-0 itom-fast 10 20 50 100 Search data for archived records

If the number of Content Groups is less than 2:

  • Extend the disk space
  • Scale out (requires extra CPU and memory)

If the number of Content Groups is 2:

  • Extend the disk space
 80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-1 itom-fast 1 20 50 100 Search data for archived records 80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-a-0 itom-fast 10 20 50 100 Search data for archived records 80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-a-1 itom-fast 1 20 50 100 Search data for archived records 80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-0 itom-fast 0.5 15 30 60 Search data for metadata

If the number of Content Groups is less than 2:

  • Extend the disk space
  • Scale out (requires extra CPU and memory)

If the number of Content Groups is 2:

  • Extend the disk space
 80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-1 itom-fast 0.5 15 30 60 Search data for metadata 80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-a-0 itom-fast 0.5 15 30 60 Search data for metadata 80% 1 month  
itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-a-1 itom-fast 0.5 15 30 60 Search data for metadata 80% 1 month  
 Total size (GB)   47 326 698 1396        

 
  • For test or development environments, in which the data volume is much smaller than in production, refer to the numbers in the Non-production column.
  • Normally, the volumes highlighted in Yellow are not in use during the first several months after go-live. This means you can start with a smaller size for these highlighted volumes. 
  • When you confirm your total size for storage, remember to calculate the standard performance storage and high performance storage size together.

This table provides both the total volume size and separate volume sizes. 

  • If you're not using StorageClass, we recommend using shared storage space–when preparing the NFS server, you only need to meet the total volume size requirement. However, if you don't want to use shared storage, separate the volume spaces according to this table. 
  • If you're using StorageClass, a provisioner will automatically create Persistent Volume Claims (PVCs) according to the volume sizes in this table.  

Storage performance recommendations

In production environments, we recommend that your storage server meets the following performance requirements.

The recommendations here are applicable to all storage volumes of the suite (both itom-standard and itom-fast) for platforms other than Azure, and applicable to AzureFile storage (which hosts the itom-standard volumes) for the Azure platform. 

Use the fio command or dd command to check both the IOPS and bandwidth or only the bandwidth of your storage server.

Use the fio command (recommended)

The fio command returns more performance information of your server than the dd command and is therefore recommended. To use this command, you need to run the yum install fio command to install it first.

The following table describes the commands and the recommended IOPS and BW (bandwidth) values. We recommend that you meet all of the recommended values. 

Command Recommendation 
fio --rw=write --bs=4k --nrfiles=50 --openfiles=10 --filesize=8m --directory=./ --name=0 -direct=1

IOPS > 3000; BW > 15 MB/s

 
fio --rw=write --bs=16k --nrfiles=20 --openfiles=10 --filesize=32m --directory=./ --name=0 -direct=1

IOPS > 3000; BW > 50 MB/s

 
fio --rw=write --bs=64k --nrfiles=20 --openfiles=10 --filesize=128m --directory=./ --name=0 -direct=1
 IOPS > 3000; BW > 200 MB/s

Use the dd command

If you can't install the fio command, use the dd command to check the bandwidth of your storage server. The following table describes the commands and recommended values. We recommend that you meet all of the recommended values.

Command Recommendation 
dd if=/dev/zero of=./a.dat bs=8k count=10k oflag=direct
 BW > 50 MB/s 
dd if=./a.dat of=/dev/null bs=8k count=1M iflag=direct
 BW > 50 MB/s 
dd if=/dev/zero of=./a.dat bs=512k count=1k oflag=direct
 BW > 1GB /s 
dd if=./a.dat of=/dev/null bs=512k count=1k iflag=direct
 BW > 500 MB/s
